Dear Mr. Laidacker:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days.
Please note that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and
your contract.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 204-6992.

ALLEGATION:
Youth ran out of their psychotropic medication at the facility which is considered a
lifesaving medication. Facility did not notify anyone about issues with filling this until
the last minute.
INVESTIGATION:
Youth A was interviewed face to face at the facility on February 17, 2022. Youth A
stated she was without Prazosin for about one week in January. Youth A reported
2

she was told by staff her insurance expired. Youth A stated she is receiving her
Prazosin now and it has not been an issue since the end of January. Youth A
denied running out of medication any other time while at the facility.
Staff 1 and Case Manager were interviewed separately, face to face at the facility on
February 17, 2022. They both stated Youth A’s foster care worker was on vacation
when the insurance became inactive, and they had to wait for the foster care worker
to return in order to fix the insurance issue. Case Manager reported she did not
attempt to call the foster care worker supervisor as she did not have the supervisor’s
phone number.
MDHHS Foster Care Worker and I exchanged emails on February 18, 2022,
regarding Youth A not receiving her Prazosin. MDHHS Foster Care Worker wrote:
01/18/2022 I was notified Youth A’s medication was out by New Hope Case
Manager in an email, and that they had gone through the reserves at the pharmacy.
This was the first I was notified, not any time prior. On 01/19/2022, I was explained it
was due to an insurance issue by Case Manager. I then notified my Health Liaison
Officer (HLO) right away to resolve the insurance issues. She did, and I then
provided contact information between the New Hope case manager and the HLO, so
if there were any further issues the HLO could assist. This insurance issue was not
an issue prior to the incident.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
 Youth Opportunity Center for Success and Independence Policies and
Procedures; Administration of Medication: correct documentation of a missed
medication and notification procedures.
 Email correspondence between MDHHS Foster Care Worker, New Hope
Caseworker, New Hope Medical Technician, and MDHHS Health Liaison
Officer between January 12 – 28, 2022 detailing insurance inactive, running
out of Prazosin, to purchase the Prazosin and save the receipt to be
reimbursed and that the insurance was now active.
 January Medication Administration Record (MAR) documenting from January
16 – January 21, 2022, Youth A did not receive her Prazosin.
APPLICABLE RULE
R 400.4142 Health services; policies and procedures.
(1) An institution shall establish and follow written health
service policies and procedures addressing all of the
following:
(e) Dispensing medication.
3

ANALYSIS: The facility is found in noncompliance as Youth A was without
Prazosin from January 16 – 21, 2022. Youth A’s insurance was
inactive. In an email the Health Liaison Officer wrote that the
prescription could be filled and once the insurance is active the
receipt could be taken back to the filling pharmacy and rerun
through Medicaid so a refund could be issued.
VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on the findings of this investigation, in conjunction with the recommendation
of SIR 2022C0128019, a first provisional license is recommended.
